content.intro:
Welcome to Edinburgh, Scotland's crown jewel perched ever so proudly on its rocky peak. It's a city with two faces—medieval and modern.

Emblem of the city and visible for kilometres around, Edinburgh Castle dominates the banks of the Firth of Forth and has a view of the far-off North Sea. It is the spectacular heart of Old Town, a neighbourhood built in the Middle Ages, with narrow winding streets, monuments, historical squares, and colourful pubs. On the other bank is New Town and its 18th-century architecture, lined with Georgian facades and Victorian houses. This lively area is full of chic boutiques, fashionable restaurants, teashops, theatres, and nightclubs, plus some beautiful gardens, including the resplendent Royal Botanic Garden.

Throughout the year, Edinburgh radiates charm and mystery: dark and stormy in winter, dazzling in spring, a balmy seaside resort in summer, and wild in the autumn. Culture reigns in this dynamic city, which has many museums, historical buildings, galleries, and festivals. It is best explored on foot, getting gloriously lost in its historical streets. Tales and legends have shaped the city, and its ghosts are still very much at home here. In fact, it has more cemeteries than any other city in the world…

Facing the sea is the long and sandy Portobello Beach. A few kilometres further north, the sea air of Leith attracts many artists, galleries, and restaurants. This is the fashionable destination for hipsters and foodies, who enjoy four starred restaurants and, of course, its Scotch whisky and craft beers. Still have a little free time? Explore the captivating surrounding countryside and then pop over to Glasgow!

content.title: The Cauldron, magic potion for happy hours

introduction.small: Largely inspired by Edinburgh's magical presence, but also by the Harry Potter saga, this cocktail bar makes truly enchanting drinks.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Cauldron, magic potion for happy hours

paragraphs.text:
Try and hold that feeling of surprise as you walk in The Cauldron. Despite the many wizard robes donned by customers, multicoloured drinks, magic wans and vials stacked on the shelves, you have not entered the Leaky Cauldron, nor is it Professor Rogue's potion room. This unusual cocktail bar does draw its inspiration from the magical universe of Harry Potter, but it remains firmly restricted to “Muggles”, that is anyone who lacks any sort of magic power. However, it will not prevent you from becoming a true wizard for the time of a drink or two.

Put on a robe, lent by the establishment, and choose among the many creative cocktails on the menu: try the Serum of Loose Lips (vodka, Aperol, peach, vanilla, lemon and milk), which the house mixologist describes as “an elixir as clear as crystal, made to reveal the truth buried deep”. Alternately, go for the Dragon's Breath (homemade strawberry syrup, freshly squeezed lime juice and white rum), topped by a fireball! You may even brew your own magic potion, with or without alcohol, during a master class. In a small cauldron from which deep smoke exudes, you will try your hand at molecular mixology and create your mix with a wand. Which is enough to reveal if you are a true wizard or not!

The Cauldron
57a Frederick Street
Edinburgh EH2 1LH

+44 131 466 1973

https://thecauldron.io/edinburgh/potions

Menu: cocktails from 10 GBP

content.title: Fazenda, for the love of meat

introduction.small: Located in the fast-growing New Town district, Fazenda blends carnivorous gastronomy with convivial spirit for a sophisticated experience.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fazenda, for the love of meat

paragraphs.text:
Brazilian gauchos turned barbecued grilled meat into an art of itself. Inherited from the fancy rodizios (all-you-can-eat buffets) of Sao Paulo's region, this tradition takes the form of the best 15 meats and cuts (beef, pork, chicken, lamb…), all available to your heart's content. Your choice will be barbecued in prime churrascaria style, later cut right at the table in front of you.

The decoration will take you right into the restaurant's atmosphere and fosters sharing and conviviality. The bar located near the entrance, as well as the large dining room with high ceilings and industrial chic style boast of sophistication quite often missing from all-you-can-eat buffets.

As a warmup, take a trip to the salad bar (stuffed peppers, onions with balsamic vinegar, a Brazilian stew, several kinds of rice, pita bread…), however you should keep some room for the most important part of the meal! The menu's seductive powers are actually bolstered by pairings with the very best Brazilian and Argentinean wines available.

Fazenda
102 George Street
Edinburgh EH2 3DF

+44 131 215 1234

https://fazenda.co.uk/edinburgh/

Menu: lunch from 18.50 GBP

content.title: Fully customizable 8-day whisky tour of Scotland

introduction.small: Explore vibrant Edinburgh and journey through the grandeur of the Scottish Highlands on an exclusive bespoke scotch whisky tour visiting ruined castles and distilleries along the way.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fully customizable 8-day whisky tour of Scotland

paragraphs.text:
A trip to Scotland is a must for whisky aficionados. Start by soaking up the culture in Edinburgh with a visit the local landmark of Edinburgh Castle and walk the Royal Mile. Sample a dram or two at the Scottish Whisky Experience – in moderation, of course – before rolling up your sleeves and making your own blend. Round off your first day in style with a gourmet dinner at the private Scotch Malt Whisky Society club.

Take time out to recharge your batteries and play a round of gold in historic St Andrews or pamper yourself in a luxurious spa. Marvel at Scotland's stunning scenery of mountains and lochs as you travel through the Scottish Highlands.

See the ancient whisky-making process for yourself during VIP tours of numerous traditional distilleries and hone your tasting skills in exclusive masterclasses on the Speyside whisky trail.

Stay in exclusive private resorts or luxury hotels and dine in high style at a prestigious castle restaurant. The perfect end to an authentic holiday.

Wine Paths

content.title: Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art

introduction.small: At the Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art, the age-old beauty of both palaces houses the best of modern and contemporary art.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art

paragraphs.text:
West of Edinburgh's city centre, two buildings of neoclassical architecture are facing each other: both built during the first half of the 19th century, Modern One and Modern Two are only separated by large lawns and a lagoon. Together, they form the National Gallery, dedicated to modern and contemporary art (from the early 1900s until today). More than 6,000 works are on display, including paintings, sculptures, installations and videos. The first palace houses temporary exhibitions (renewed every six months) as well as the masterpieces of Cubism, Abstract and Pop Art, well represented by Matisse, Picasso, David Hockney and Andy Warhol. The second building will win you over with the work of surrealists Dalí, Magritte and Giacometti. Sculptor Eduardo Paolozzi is also given pride of place since his entire art studio has been recreated on the premises! A well-stocked library and archive storage are also on site, including more than 2,500 rare editions accessible to the public in the reading rooms.
End your visit of this majestic cultural ground, now well-established in the capital, by wandering around the English garden riddled with giant sculptures.

Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art
75 Belford Road
Edinburg EH4 3DR

+44 131 624 6200

https://www.nationalgalleries.org/visit/scottish-national-gallery-modern-art

content.title: The Leonardo Royal Hotel Edinburgh Haymarket, a modern soul

introduction.small: Whether for business or tourism, the Leonardo Royal Hotel Edinburgh Haymarket plunges you into the life of the Scottish capital.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Leonardo Royal Hotel Edinburgh Haymarket, a modern soul

paragraphs.text:
Only five minutes away from the historical centre of the city, the Leonardo Royal Hotel Edinburgh Haymarket welcomes businessmen, groups and families in a modern and friendly atmosphere. Princes Street, Old Town and the Castle of Edinburgh will all satisfy tourists looking for a stroll, whereas the nearby conference centre houses various types of conventions. This four-star is very appealing and well-situated, and also offers a car park, which is no small feat in the capital!
In the 282 rooms that the establishment counts, you will find reproductions of local maps, as well as the city's main monuments, thus giving a touch of fantasy to the subdued and stylish furniture. The latter actually contrasts with the vintage setting and the pastel tones of the hotel's restaurant, which serves classics such as cheeseburgers, fish & chips and risottos at any time of day or night. A Scottish buffet will also await you for breakfast, which is probably the best way to start off the day!

The Leonardo Royal Hotel Edinburgh Haymarket
1 Morrison Link
Edinburgh EH3 8DN

+44 131 460 4600

https://www.leonardohotels.co.uk/hotels/edinburgh/leonardo-royal-hotel-edinburgh-haymarket

Rooms: from 59 GBP

content.title: The Scran and Scallie, Edinburgh's reference gastro-pub

introduction.small: Sprung from the imagination of two starred chefs, Tom Kitchin and Dominic Jack, the Scran & Scallie is the new meeting ground for Edinburgh's food lovers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Scran and Scallie, Edinburgh's reference gastro-pub

paragraphs.text:
In local dialect, scran means "food" and scallie is the short for "scallywag". Two of Scotland's best chefs have teamed up and created this place at once recognised for the quality of the food, based on regional and seasonal products, as well as its friendly atmosphere.
The concept skilfully blends traditions and modernity: bricks, celadon-blue tones on the walls and filament bulbs create a warm decor that will immediately plunge you into a high-end culinary experience, drawing its inspiration from Scottish gastronomy and taking it to new heights of creativity. Aside from the famous haggis (stuffed sheep stomach) and various puddings, the homemade beef sausage or the steak of smoked salmon served with scrambled duck eggs and asparagus are only some of the dishes you have to try. An original and gastronomic way to discover local specialities.

The Scran & Scallie
1 Comely Bank Road
Stockbridge
Edinburgh EH4 1DT

+44 131 332 6281

https://scranandscallie.com

Menu: from 31 GBP

content.title: Eden Locke, a quiet bubble in the centre of the city

introduction.small: In Edinburgh's central district, the Eden Locke apartments are a haven of peace you will never want to leave.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Eden Locke, a quiet bubble in the centre of the city

paragraphs.text:
With a perfect location amid the capital, surrounded by bars, restaurants and countless shops, Eden Locke has managed to find balance between calm, casualness and trendiness. The soft pastel tones used, as well as the clear oak floors and various plants growing in terracotta pots establish the style created by the Grzywinski+Pons architecture agency, voluntarily contrasting with the more classical-looking Georgian façade.
The hotel counts 72 autonomous rooms with equipped kitchens, offering visitors a long-term rental option with no constraints. In addition, various activities are being offered, such as conferences and yoga classes in partnership with the studio located on Canning Street, right on the corner. As for visiting tourists, they will be seduced by the cosy simplicity of the furniture as well as the natural light piercing through the large windows, not to mention the district's historical beauty.

Eden Locke
127 George Street
Edinburgh EH2 4JN

+44 330 056 3363

https://www.lockeliving.com/eden-locke/

Rooms: from 75 GBP

content.title: In the green alleys of the Royal Mile

introduction.small: Within Edinburgh, a small haven of peace exists, preserved from the perpetual excitement of the city's most famous street, the Royal Mile.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: In the green alleys of the Royal Mile

paragraphs.text:
The Royal Mile, as it is popularly known, is a collection of narrow streets and courtyards in Edinburgh that make up the almost two-kilometre long main artery of the old city. Popular with visitors, it conceals some secrets that are well kept by its inhabitants.

Embark on a tour of the Scottish capital, off the beaten path: welcome to the Dunbars Close Garden, discreet gardens of the Royal Mile hidden behind houses with quirky architecture and high modern buildings. Developed with the aim of creating some islands of greenery, contrasting with the urbanisation and mass tourism of Edinburgh's most famous street, you can explore these spots on your own on a leisurely walk through the heart of the city, or book a tour with an experienced guide. Look out for you may pass them by without even noticing!

Dunbars Close Garden
Canongate
High Street
Edinburgh EH8 8BW

+44 131 529 5151

https://www.edinburghoutdoors.org.uk/featureDetails.php?id=36

content.title: Scottish hospitality at the Rutland

introduction.small: At the hotel Rutland, a made-to-measure welcome that echoes the refinement of its rooms. Feel like a real Scot in this unique place, filled with history.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Scottish hospitality at the Rutland

paragraphs.text:
Walk through the door to the Rutland Hotel to a building steeped in history. The place was once the home of a British baron but has been renovated as a hotel. In each of the twelve rooms and nine autonomous apartments, the elements of decoration bring a point of colour, contrasting with the white sheets and headboards in a more contemporary style. As for the bathrooms, they give pride of place to the most modern comfort.

The hotel is a pleasant cocoon where you can enjoy your stay. Muffins and traditional shortbreads will be offered upon your arrival with a mug of tea or coffee-whichever you prefer.

For dining, there is no need to leave the hotel: the Huxley Bar or the Kyloe Steak Restaurant & Grill will satisfy your appetite at lunch and dinner. In the basement hides a… gin distillery - a perfect place to have a nightcap in an intimate atmosphere.

The Rutland Hotel
1-3 Rutland Street
Edinburgh EH1 2AE

+44 131 229 3402

https://www.therutlandhotel.com/

Rooms: from 126 GBP

content.title: The Last Word Saloon invents the cocktail of your dreams

introduction.small: If you appreciate being surprised by new tastes, spend an evening at the Last Word Saloon, you will not be disappointed.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Last Word Saloon invents the cocktail of your dreams

paragraphs.text:
Nowhere better than the Last Word Saloon, in the Stockbridge neighbourhood, to enjoy (in moderation) some very creative cocktails, including improbable mixtures that will delight your desire for delectable liqueurs. Awaken all your senses by experimenting with new flavours through creative and unobtrusive combinations. Mike Aikman and Jason Scott, the owners of this 'paradise' for those who love a good night out, dream up original cocktails such as the Night Circus, a blend of rum, chocolate liquor, balsamic vinegar and vanilla, or the Butter-Scotch Cocktail, with its unique mix of whisky, butter, Aperol, vanilla and ginger jam. If you prefer, the Last Word Saloon also offers an excellent wine and beer list. A warm atmosphere in a typical setting where sheepskin rugs and crackling fires make you feel right at home.

The Last Word Saloon
44 St Stephen Street
Stockbridge

+44 131 225 9009

www.lastwordsaloon.com

Drinks: from 3.5 GBP

content.title: Cramond, an isle of mystery

introduction.small: Off the coast of Edinburgh on the Forth River, a small island only accessible at low tide traces the history of Scotland during the Second World War.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cramond, an isle of mystery

paragraphs.text:
Strange, isn't it? Cramond Island has been floating on the waters of the Forth for thousands of years, just a few kilometres off the Scottish capital. The eponymous village, accessible by bus from downtown Edinburgh, runs along a vast beach caressed by regular tides. You merely have to wait for low tide to walk the long pathway thus revealed that connects the Scottish village with its island counterpart. Imposing concrete figures, aligned like soldiers facing the seafront, reinforce the mysterious character of the island, now abandoned to the fate of a few passing explorers.

Long home to sheep breeding, the village of Cramond was covered with numerous guard towers, bunkers and barracks to house Allied troops during the Second World War. Today, this island is no longer in use and remains suspended out of time, making it all the more fascinating.

Cramond Island
Firth of Forth
Edinburgh EH4 6NU

content.title: A lovely walk in Princes Street Gardens

introduction.small: This huge green space in the very heart of Edinburgh is a real invitation for the whole family to relax.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A lovely walk in Princes Street Gardens

paragraphs.text:
Princes Street Gardens, the largest park in central Edinburgh, separates the old town from the new. Divided into several gardens, the 150,000 sqm gardens stand on the exact site of Nor Loch, an ancient lake which, in the Middle Ages, served as the city's natural defence. Inaugurated in 1820, the Princes Street Gardens were created following the drainage of a vast expanse of water as part of the development of the city towards the north.

Wander among trees and groves and pause for a moment to contemplate the Ross Fountain erected in 1872 – a sumptuous structure in golden cast iron, with sculptures of sirens and four women, representing the arts, sciences, poetry and industry, surmounted by a fifth with the Horn of Plenty. To the west of the park, the floral clock, made up of thousands of plants, sounds the hours, while children enjoy the slides and rides on a large playground entirely for them.

Princes Street Gardens
Princes Street
Edinburgh EH2 2HG

+44 131 529 7921

https://www.edinburghoutdoors.org.uk

content.title: Purslane's casual fine dining

introduction.small: In the basement of a grand Georgian-style home, Purslane is akin to a secret address. Don't hesitate to venture inside and taste Paul Gunning's refined cooking.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Purslane's casual fine dining

paragraphs.text:
Just minutes from the centre of Edinburgh, the Stockbridge neighbourhood retained the look of a picturesque village. At the corner of St. Stephen Street, go down a few steps to discover a hidden restaurant. The cream and deep chocolate tones of the room and its wooden tables provide Purslane with a very cosy atmosphere. Chef Paul Gunning will reveal what he likes to call “casual fine dining cuisine” at this delightful spot.
Mainly composed of fresh and local products, dishes are rich, flavourful and colourful. The thick steak of beef and its meltingly soft potatoes, wild mushrooms, roasted small vegetables and red wine sauce, as well as the marinated salmon in fennel and beetroot are simply exquisite. Also take a look at the wine list – you will find exactly what you are looking for with wines that will perfectly pair with your chosen dish.

Purslane Restaurant
33A St Stephen Street
Stockbridge
Edinburgh EH3 5AH

+44 131 226 3500

www.purslanerestaurant.co.uk

Menu: around 35 GBP

content.title: North Coast 500, the mythical Scottish road

introduction.small: This really wild road leads up to the Orkney Islands. Discover a picture-postcard view of Scotland, which remained unchanged since time immemorial.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: North Coast 500, the mythical Scottish road

paragraphs.text:
For from usual tours, choose a road trip in the Scottish back country, filled with nature and history. When leaving Edinburgh, you cross over Speyside before taking the North Coast 500 in Inverness. Be sure to fill up the car's tank before going, as gas stations are scarce on the way! As it is only a two-lane road, you may also get stuck behind a carload of whisky or a herd of sheep. Take that as an opportunity to admire the endless landscape. In springtime, the horizon appears to be pink, while in autumn is changes from yellow to brown. You'll discover a wild countryside, gorgeous vistas, genuine Scottish castles and unspoiled beaches. You will meet herds of sheep and cows but no human beings. Where do the Scottish go?
Further North, the light changes. Depending on the weather, you may discern the rocky and wild Orkney Islands. It is at Scapa Flow that the German fleet was sunk in 1919. Wreckage is still at sea. Baffling sensation!

https://www.northcoast500.com

content.title: Royal Burgess: the origins of golf!

introduction.small: Scots are not only passionate about golf, they also claim to have invented it! A golf course at the legendary Royal Burgess is therefore in order.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Royal Burgess: the origins of golf!

paragraphs.text:
Scotland is the land of golf, counting over 500 courses. Twenty or so are located in the Edinburgh area, totalling over 100 km and 342 holes to play.
Ten minutes away from the city centre, the Royal Burgess is legendary. It is one of the only ten listed as Royal in the whole Kingdom, and its society is the oldest in the world as it was founded in 1735. Filled with century-old trees, the green is as was in year 1895 (slightly modified once in 1945). If not the most complex or technical, the course is nevertheless appreciated for its quality and charm. You could count the late Sir Sean Connery (yes, Bond, James Bond himself) among the regulars! Tournaments are adapted to both junior and senior players. Not-to-be-missed is the clubhouse, developing a very Scottish welcoming...

Royal Burgess Golfing Society of Edinburgh
181 Whitehouse Road
Barnton
Edinburgh EH4 6BU

+44 1313 39 2075

https://www.royalburgess.co.uk

content.title: Dalwhinnie: the highest distillery in Scotland

introduction.small: In the land of whisky, it is impossible not to visit a distillery. This one is at once one of the oldest and most typical.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dalwhinnie: the highest distillery in Scotland

paragraphs.text:
Are you looking for genuine a whisky tasting, or even curious of how it is made? Then you ought to visit a traditional Scottish distillery. To do so, leave Edinburgh and drive up the A9. Once you go by Drumochter Pass, often snowy even in Summer, the distillery appears all dressed in white, seemingly floating over a tawny mattress. During the Victorian era, distilleries were built in the most remote parts of Scotland. Here, at 300 m above the sea level, you are steeped in an impressive landscape of grey mountains. The Dalwhinnie building itself has remained as it has ever been since its creation in 1897. The wash backs are made of wood and the stills are in copper.
It produces only one, 15 years old, single malt that reflects its unique character. The honey flavour comes from clear spring water and the floral flavours from the heather it lies on. Its aftertaste is a bit dry, rough like the climate. Of course, whisky lovers and amateurs alike will appreciate the tasting organised after the visit.

Dalwhinnie Distillery
General Wade's Military Rd
Dalwhinnie PH19 1AA

+44 1540 67 2219

https://www.malts.com/en-row/distilleries/dalwhinnie

content.title: National Museum of Scotland, a big historical deal…

introduction.small: An essential visit, this museum is dedicated to the history, culture, and traditions of Scotland—take a fascinating tour and admire the exceptional scenography.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: National Museum of Scotland, a big historical deal…

paragraphs.text:
Opened in 1998, the National Museum of Scotland, graced with beautiful architecture, hosts permanent and travelling exhibitions. A treasure trove of Scottish heritage, the museum provides a fun and fascinating overview of both the country's history and natural sciences (especially regarding paleontology). Through more than 10,000 objects, it introduces the visitor to the world of the earliest Scots, the birth of a nation, and the country as it stands today. Expect an educational approach complimented by pleasing displays.
Do not miss the Cramond Lioness, a Roman sculpture, the old tombstones, or the 11 ivory pieces from a Viking chess set. The section on the country's industrial development is particularly interesting, with its gorgeous model ships, steam trains, and automated animals. A place with something for all generations - and entrance is free of charge!

National Museum of Scotland
Chambers Street
Edinburgh EH1 1JF

+44 300 123 6789

https://www.nms.ac.uk/national-museum-of-scotland/

content.title: Malmaison, a former sailor haunt

introduction.small: Located 15 minutes from Edinburgh, near the medieval port of Leith, this beautiful 19th-century building houses a boutique hotel with a maritime atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Malmaison, a former sailor haunt

paragraphs.text:
In the small town of Leith, head to the docks and the imposing Malmaison, with its central tower and chiming clock. The typically Scottish building houses 100 rooms and suites on four floors. The spacious rooms feature a classic, chic and cosy decor with tartan prints and elegant stripes. The bathrooms are chequered in black and white, like the lobby. The atmosphere is posh bourgeois, with family portraits on the walls. The brass rail of the grand central staircase shines brightly, and the front door is original.
To eat, go to the European-style brasserie in Victorian London decor, with leather sofas and armchairs. At teatime, if weather permits, enjoy a cup on the terrace, or pop over to the Royal Yacht Britannia. Moored in the port of Leith, Queen Elizabeth's old ship is open to the public. A visit not to be missed...

Malmaison
1 Tower Place
Edinburgh EH6 7BZ

+44 131 285 1478

https://www.malmaison.com/locations/edinburgh/

Rooms: from 75 GBP

content.title: Holyroodhouse Palace: a royal residence

introduction.small: Queen Elizabeth II's official royal palace in Scotland, Holyroodhouse sits at the bottom of Edinburgh's Royal Mile and has spectacular views of Arthur's Seat.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Holyroodhouse Palace: a royal residence

paragraphs.text:
Built on the ruins of the Church of the Holy Rude, this Baroque palace regularly hosts members of the royal family during special celebrations and ceremonies. It is, however, possible to visit when it is not occupied. It is a place closely associated with the turbulent history of Scotland and the glory of Mary, Queen of Scots. The centrepiece in the apartments of the illustrious queen is her bedroom, especially the bed where Mary nearly lost the child she was carrying, following the heinous murder of her supposed favourite—a murder ordered by the king consort himself, Henry Stuart, known as ‘Lord Darnley.' The traces of blood on the ground could never be cleaned and are still visible! Continue the tour with the great gallery adorned with portraits of the kings of Scotland, painted by Jacob de Wet. Inaugurated by Queen Elizabeth in 2002, the Queen's Gallery hosts an extensive programme of exhibitions of treasures from the Royal Collection.

Palace of Holyroodhouse
Canongate
The Royal Mile
Edinburgh EH8 8DX

+44 303 123 7306

https://www.rct.uk/visit/palace-of-holyroodhouse

content.title: In pursuit of ghosts and other macabre spirits

introduction.small: Traditionally, the Scottish capital likes to tell its black tales and scary stories of yore. The number of popular tours focussing on murder, mystery and ghosts is ever increasing.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: In pursuit of ghosts and other macabre spirits

paragraphs.text:
Walk in the footsteps of popular and fantastic tales straight out of the fertile imagination of Scottish writers like Robert Louis Stevenson (The Strange Case of Doctor Jekyll and Mister Hyde), Arthur Conan Doyle, and, more recently, Ian Rankin. These authors have recounted stories of witchcraft, terrifying murders, and infamous torture... and today these legends are staged as night visits. Warning: sensitive souls refrain!
On the “Haunted Vaults” tour, while traversing the sinister alleys and backyards of Old Town, you will discover places where murders and supernatural phenomena took place. It is a journey guaranteed to give goosebumps! Your ghostly guide combines history and humour with facts and fables, and a few appalling apparitions are sure to show up along the way. For the “Vaults and Graveyard” tour, your guide will be none other than Alexander Clapperton, the director of the Edinburgh cemetery in the 1840s! Fright nights ahead…

Auld Reekie Tours
45 Niddry Street
Edinburgh EH1 1LG

+44 131 557 4700

https://www.auldreekietours.com/

content.title: The Elephant House: in the footsteps of Harry Potter

introduction.small: A restaurant, but also a pub and a world-famous tearoom, this is where JK Rowling wrote the first volume of her blockbuster saga.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Elephant House: in the footsteps of Harry Potter

paragraphs.text:
Following the release of the first Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone book in 1997, The Elephant House has become an attraction in itself. For it is in the second room of the establishment that J.K. Rowling, the novelist who wrote the most famous literary saga of recent years, spent her days writing the novel. And guess what? The windows face... Edinburgh Castle, which most definitely was an inspiration for the Hogwarts universe, with its magicians and evil wizards. Fans now snap selfies in front of the red facade and crowd inside for lunch, dinner, or a cup of warm tea.
A relaxed atmosphere and welcoming smile make this café a popular meeting place. The food is Tex-Mex and Italian, but there are also typical dishes such as haggis (stuffed sheep stomach) with mashed potatoes and turnips. Tip: save room for the delicious desserts, best enjoyed in the back room. Look out for bursts of creativity!

The Elephant House
21 George IV Bridge
Edinburgh EH1 1EN

+44 131 466 0873

https://elephanthouse.biz/

Menu: around 16 GBP

content.title: Portobello: a seaside resort on the outskirts of Edinburgh

introduction.small: Take advantage of this long white sandy beach, just minutes from downtown. This is one of the favourite walks of Edinburghers, who flock here with the first rays of sun.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Portobello: a seaside resort on the outskirts of Edinburgh

paragraphs.text:
Considered by some as a neighbourhood of Edinburgh, by others as part of its suburbs, Portobello is very close to downtown-just five kilometres northeast, roughly 15 minutes by bus. Head straight to the beach for a refreshing and romantic stroll. The sea is sublime, but know that the temperature rarely rises above 19°C, even in high season. This does not stop some from swimming in winter.
In summer, the beach comes alive: yacht clubs open their doors, vacationers settle in, pubs set out their deck chairs, and Victorian homes regain their original charm. Many small cafés offer takeaway food. Have a picnic, feet in the sand, munching on fish and chips. Gourmet types will want to visit the traditional market, which takes place every Saturday on Brighton Park. Meanwhile, sports fans can attend-or even participate in-a volleyball competition, or go kayaking or sailing.

content.title: Garden cuisine at The Gardener's Cottage

introduction.small: In the neighbourhood of Calton Hill, two talented chefs in a charming 19th-century cottage offer impeccable organic cooking.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Garden cuisine at The Gardener's Cottage

paragraphs.text:
The pitch is simple: a gardener's stone hut, with adjoining garden, and two experienced chefs, Dale Mailley and Edward Murray, who love organic products, healthy, seasonal, and local if possible. Together they embarked on an adventure of taste. The atmosphere is casual chic, with a long dinner table in aged wood as the room's centrepiece. In this picturesque setting, conversation comes easily, and the atmosphere is immediately friendly.
On offer are weekday lunches, brunch on weekends, and, in the evening 'discovery' menus of three to six dishes, each perfectly sized to showcase their spectacular flavours. And these are many: herbs from the garden, smoked pigeon, roasted fish, truffles, local cheeses like the Old Winchester, pearl barley, sourdough bread, and, for dessert, buttermilk panna cotta with Yorkshire rhubarb and atsina cress with a liquorice taste. A delight, especially on the weekends, when jazz music is added to the mix.

content.title: Rosslyn Chapel: the Templar legend

introduction.small: Located 12 km south of Edinburgh, this enigmatic chapel was popularised by the novel The Da Vinci Code and by the film of the same name shot ​​inside its walls.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Rosslyn Chapel: the Templar legend

paragraphs.text:
Built in 1446 by Lord William St Clair, Rosslyn Chapel is the most mysterious building in Scotland. It has puzzled clerics and other scholars for centuries. Its architecture reveals many templar symbols and allegorical images linked to freemasonry, while the walls are covered with paintings depicting knights, a nativity scene, and Lucifer hung upside down by his feet… None of this is all that surprising: Lord William St Clair was linked to the Scottish Freemasonry.
Knights Templar legends still fire the imaginations of visitors. It was after visiting Rosslyn Chapel in 2001 that Dan Brown had the idea for what later became The Da Vinci Code. Even more surprising are sculptural elements representing corncobs dating from 1460 – well before the discovery of America by Christopher Columbus. How is this possible? To date, no explanation has been found… This Old Lady still holds many secrets within…

content.title: Stirling Castle: the memory of the past

introduction.small: Located 58 km from Edinburgh, the castle has a history closely linked to Scotland's. A fortress and a royal palace, it was repeatedly besieged by the English.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Stirling Castle: the memory of the past

paragraphs.text:
As massive and solid as rock, this imposing castle, built atop a rocky promontory, has been destroyed and rebuilt more than once. It has a strategic position in the region, as it paves the way to the Highlands, making it a desired object and the locus of many battles. The most famous, in 1297, was the first Scottish victory over the English army. This was followed a few years later (1314) by the Battle of Bannockburn, which allowed the Scotland of Robert Bruce to regain its independence.
In the 15th century, the castle became one of the residences of the Stuart kings. Mary was crowned Queen of Scots here in 1543; her son, the future James VI, was crowned here in 1566, as was her grandson in 1594. Its architecture and remarkable French Renaissance ornamentation date from this time. It remains a place charged with history.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Saunter down Victoria Street to Grassmarket

Curving, charming Victoria Street runs from the Royal Mile to Grassmarket, the old herb market. This fun shopping district is full of small artisan shops with brightly coloured facades, offering the city's best tartans, cashmere, and designer brands. You can also come across some exhibition venues, including The Red Door Gallery, specialising in posters and prints by Scottish artists. Pubs punctuate this postcard setting.
The joyful atmosphere extends to the old marketplace at the foot of the castle, with its many cafés and vintage shops. Do not miss the Fabhatrix designer hats, prehistoric items at Mr. Wood's Fossils or a leather jacket at Armstrongs Vintage Emporium, second-hand clothes shop since 1840. Forget the traces of the past-Grassmarket was once the site of public executions-because this painful period has now given way to one of sparkling vitality.

content.title: The Scotch Whisky Experience: a museum of whisky

introduction.small: To discover the history, production, and taste of the Scottish national drink, go to this temple dedicated to single malts.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Scotch Whisky Experience: a museum of whisky

paragraphs.text:
You cannot visit Edinburgh without sampling its famous whisky. Located on the Royal Mile, in a former school, The Scotch Whisky Experience offers a playful, enlightening, and tasty introduction to this divine nectar. You travel in a special whiskey barrel car, which takes you through the different steps and manufacturing processes. The interactive ride-available in 15 languages-teaches you all about whisky fermentation, distillation, and maturation.
Finally, the long-awaited moment: the tasting. You will sample up to four different whiskies-always in moderation, of course! Use your sense of smell and try to slowly pinpoint the various aromas of this local speciality. In the adjacent room, through a glass wall, you will find the largest collection of Scotch whisky in the world, consisting of 3,500 bottles, some of which are stored, under guard, in an ultramodern safe.

Housed in a former lumber warehouse, Timberyard is chic and minimalist, and the food is exceptional. From appetisers to dessert, every dish is creatively prepared and superbly executed. The rest of the Radford family is in either the dining room or the bar, as the Timberyard has become a beautiful family success story for Lisa and Andrew, who work in perfect harmony with their children Ben, Jo, and Abi. Housed in an old whisky warehouse, this unique restaurant has held on to its industrial heritage. Inside, the natural blue of stone, wood, and metal is warmed by beautiful cerulean and brown fabrics. Through the large window into the kitchen, watch the cooks at their stoves, executing a modern cuisine influenced by the techniques of French cooking. content.title: The Real Mary King's Close: a voyage through time

introduction.small: Explore a world of mystery just steps from the Royal Mile. Right under the South Bridge arches, you will actually find a genuine medieval maze.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Real Mary King's Close: a voyage through time

paragraphs.text:
The present city having been built over the old, it is possible to go back in time by descending into Edinburgh's bowels. The underground areas provide exact 'photographs' of Edinburgh as it was in the 16th century. A few feet below the surface, accompanied by an erudite guide, you will encounter a forgotten medieval city, the “Close”, surprisingly hidden under the town's liveliest street. The guides are unbeatable: full of stories and anecdotes, with each-don't worry- possessed of a flawless sense of direction! A strange world awaits you, with its rather frightening maze of streets. Yet this is where the locals lived and worked, from the 16th century well into the 19th century. The place is cold, dark, and maybe even haunted... hence the many myths and legends surrounding it. On your way, you may witness that The Real Mary King's Close is revived by actors in period costumes, telling the stories of its inhabitants. An unforgettable visit!

In the historical centre, head to Victoria Street to discover this luxury sandwich shop. content.title: Camera Obscura: explore a world beyond reality

introduction.small: Creative and fun, this museum is devoted to optical illusions and other amazing effects, including those provided by a camera obscura that allows you to spy on the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Camera Obscura: explore a world beyond reality

paragraphs.text:
Located just steps from Edinburgh Castle, this museum is worth visiting, especially with family. Housed in an old watchtower on four levels, its main attraction is at the very top: an enormous camera obscura, dating from the 19th century, which projects several simultaneous views of the city. These ingenious sets of mirrors are used to spy on the surroundings and all the actions of the people within them. On entering the dark room, you will feel like a giant in a world of Lilliputians.
The third-floor houses optical illusions and numerous workshops and activities. Then there are the holograms, all larger than life. On the lower level, another enchanting scene awaits you, made ​​of mirrors and lenses. Finally, the last amusing step: a maze of ice, which proves not that easy to navigate!

Welcome to Scotland in this legendary hotel built in traditional Scottish architectural style in 1902. The meeting place for celebrities, its best ambassador was none other than Sir Sean Connery, the world's most famous Scot. Here, doormen in kilts and Balmoral berets usher you into the large Victorian lobby. Between tradition and modernity, designer Olga Polizzi has managed to infuse the place with a contemporary twist, all the while preserving 'the Scottish soul' of the 167 rooms and 20 suites, which have exceptional views of Edinburgh Castle and Old Town. The night promises to be sweet, rocked by such charming and luxurious touches.
For dining, the Balmoral excels with its two restaurants, including the Michelin starred Number One. At teatime, Palm Court is still as popular as it was in the days when the Queen Mother used to drop in. Whisky? The bar Scotch has a selection of close to 400 from Scotland alone.

content.title: Admire Edinburgh from the top of Arthur's Seat

introduction.small: Scots and tourists alike brave gale winds to enjoy the hill's magnificent 360-degree views of the city and its surroundings.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Admire Edinburgh from the top of Arthur's Seat

paragraphs.text:
Arthur's Seat stands out impressively when viewed from many parts of the city. It is located atop an extinct volcano some 350 million years old, where an archaeological site revealed signs of human activity (notably tools made of flint and stone), up to 7,000 years before our time. This spectacular 251-m hill in the centre of Holyrood Park is a particularly popular walking destination, especially on weekends. The steep climb is no easy task-it takes 20 to 30 minutes to reach the top-but the spectacular panorama is well worth it.
Several routes up are possible, but the east side, from St Margaret's Loch, is the most advisable. The payoff at the peak is the breath-taking view, especially on summer evenings: the sunsets are magical. For the descent, go to the south side through Duddingston, where you can pop into the famous Sheep Heid Inn tavern, with its lovely lawn-bowling pitch.

Opened in the 17th century in the north of the city, this garden has a unique collection of plants from around the world and one of the largest groupings of herbaria in Europe. Visit the Chinese pagoda and the Palm House, an elegant Victorian building which houses giant palm trees and a gallery illustrating the evolution of plants. The greenhouses are magnificent – the largest measures an incredible 168 by 18 m.
Entrance to the buildings costs 5 GBP but remains free for children under 15. The revenues help fund its scientific centre for plant research, for the primary purpose of this garden is to study medicinal plants. It's a magical place, whatever the season...

content.title: Sleeping in a historical castle

Today, you can sleep in one of the castle's 29 luxurious rooms. Maybe you will meet the ghost of Lady Catherine of Dalhousie, a caring soul who is said to still roam the house in search of her lost love.

One of the suites even has a gorgeous canopy bed, a true museum piece. Once installed, head to the reception via the central staircase. Library, dining room ceremonial hall, lounges: you can wander at your leisure through these spaces, all adorned with heavy drapes and precious carpets. content.title: The legends of Bobby and the ghost

introduction.small: Who doesn't know Greyfriars, the oldest cemetery in Edinburgh? This is where the dog Bobby watched over his missing master and where the ‘Bloody Mackenzie' ghost supposedly still lurks…

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The legends of Bobby and the ghost

paragraphs.text:
Visit Greyfriars cemetery in the heart of Old Town to learn the touching story of Bobby, the Skye terrier who, in the mid-19th century, mourned the death of his master for 14 years. Inconsolable, he stayed day and night next to the grave. This romance so moved the people that, in 1872, the dog was buried next to his late owner. In memory of this unwavering loyalty, a full-size statue of the dog was erected at the entrance of the cemetery. Today still, Bobby of Greyfriars remains a symbol of fidelity for all Scots.
Another story attached to this place, more chilling this time, is that of George Mackenzie, an executioner who horribly persecuted his victims. Legend has it that his ghost still roams here, attacking visitors who venture too close to the vaults. Some tour operators organise night tours of the cemetery, but even a day trip will suffice to give you an appreciation for its strange and spooky atmosphere.

content.title: 94DR: a bed and breakfast with character

paragraphs.text:
Located in the residential area of ​​Edinburgh, this Victorian house is a five-minute walk from Arthur's Seat and a ten-minute drive from the city centre. White and grey with a touch of black: these are the three dominant colours in the decor. In the rooms, the colour palette also includes some notes of green, red, or orange. Volumes are nice and the bow windows look out onto Arthur's Seat, the Pentland Hills, or the establishment's garden. Owners Paul and John, two art enthusiasts, are big fans of modern Scottish works, and many examples are hanging on the walls.
They're also passionate about food. Paul puts together full Scottish breakfasts that are as beautiful as they are delicious, inventive, and hearty. The dinner menu offers contemporary cuisine, or you could cycle to one of the small restaurants in the area on a hotel-provided bike.

94DR
94 Dalkeith Road
Edinburgh EH16 5AF

+44 131 662 9265

94dr.co.uk/

Rooms: from 120 GBP

content.title: Nira Caledonia: a chic and confidential address

introduction.small: Discreet and elegant, this boutique hotel on a little cobbled street in New Town is a haven of comfort, just minutes from the city centre.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Nira Caledonia: a chic and confidential address

paragraphs.text:
On top of a steep street lined with shops and restaurants stands this charming property, consisting of two Georgian houses. Here, time seems to have stopped—in the 19th century, when the famous essayist Christopher North lived here. Upon arrival, you fall under the spell of this mixture of classicism and modernity, which both delights and reassures. There is no elevator to reach the 28 rooms and suites; instead, you will find a magnificently romantic spiral staircase.
The rooms, large and small, are bedecked in chic stripes, tartans, and tweeds in warm hues. The furniture is decidedly Scottish. The suites each have a lounge area and three have Jacuzzis. Room service is available round the clock, using only the best Scottish produce. The chief advocates local and organic food: mussels and fish from the mountain lochs and farm lamb from the famous butcher Puddledub. The bar looks like a private club and offers a great list of scotches, both blends and single malts.

Nira Caledonia
6-10 Gloucester Place
Edinburgh EH3 6EF

+44 131 225 2720

https://www.niracaledonia.com/

Rooms: from 106 GBP

content.title: Edinburgh Castle: a key symbol of the city

introduction.small: This imposing edifice, perched high up on its craggy rock, dominates the town and its surroundings. An entire chapter of royal history has played out behind its thick stone walls.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Edinburgh Castle: a key symbol of the city

paragraphs.text:
Set into the hills of Edinburgh, the castle's silhouette of impressive strength and character imposes itself regardless of where you are in the city. Inside lies a small town, and a visit here takes you on an incredible journey in time. Start with St Margaret's Chapel, built in the 12th century, making it the oldest building in Edinburgh.
Then visit its other treasures, among them the Scottish crown jewels, the exceptional Stone of Destiny, and Mons Meg, a huge 15th-century cannon. Legend has it that you can sometimes hear the 'headless drummer', who warned of the arrival of Cromwell and the anti-royalists when they besieged the castle in 1650. The tour continues in the prisons, which teem with details of the daily lives of former prisoners. Do not miss the richly decorated banquet hall, seat of the Scottish Court for a long time. The castle is the most visited monument in the country, and the most haunted...

Edinburgh Castle
Castlehill
Edinburgh EH1 2NG

+44 131 225 9846

https://www.edinburghcastle.scot

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Edinburgh
content.introduction: With the influence of the Gulf Stream, Scotland has a temperate oceanic climate. Abundant and often unpredictable rains fall throughout the year. The temperatures are very mild from June to September (the preferred season for tourism) and relatively mild during the winter months from December to March. Beware of the biting winds from the northern mountains, close to the Arctic Circle.

airports.title: Edinburgh International Airport
airports.description:
The Edinburgh international airport is located 13 km (8 miles) west of the city centre.
  • 1 terminal

Getting from the airport to Edinburgh and back:
  • By car:
    • Access: the centre of Edinburgh is a 20-minute drive from the airport, on the A8 freeway.
    • Parking facilities:
  • A short-term parking lot is located at the exit of the terminal (a 2-minute walk). Price: GBP 9 for 30 minutes, GBP 12 for 1 hour.
  • Long-term parking, easily accessible with a free shuttle (7-minute ride), costs GBP 7 for 1 hour, GBP 40 for 24 hours and GBP 75 for 48 hours.
    • Several car rental companies are available in the airport arrivals area.
  • By tram: A tramline runs between the airport and the city centre in 30 minutes (every 15 minutes, between 6:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m.).
    The price of an adult ticket is GBP 6.50 for a one-way ticket and GBP 9 for a return ticket. For a child the fare is GBP 3.30 one-way and GBP 4.80 for a return ticket. Tickets are on sale in distributors located at the tram station. Please note that the price of tickets sold on board the tram is much higher: GBP 10.
  • By shuttle: The Airlink 100 buses operate a shuttle between the airport and the city centre. They run 24/7, all year long, at a rate of one bus every 12 minutes. Fares: GBP 4.50 for an adult one-way ticket and GBP 7.50 for a return ticket, GBP 2 for a child one-way ticket and GBP 3 for a return ticket. You can purchase your ticket from the shuttle driver.
  • By taxi: You will easily find taxis outside the airport arrivals area. Fares to Edinburgh city centre range from GBP 25 to GBP 30, depending on the time, the day of the week and the traffic. Allow about 25 minutes for the journey.
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, duty-free, free Internet access (Wi-Fi), currency exchange desks, ATMs, post office, left baggage and lost objects counter are all available in the airport.
  • Telephone: 0844 448 8833 (charge of a local call) / +44 (0)131 348 4203
  • Website: https://www.edinburghairport.com

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Edinburgh
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Edinburgh each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: January 1-2: New Year (national)
events.description: The new year is enthusiastically celebrated in Scotland! People gather on the streets, in pubs and restaurants to dance and toast to new beginnings. On January 1<sup>st</sup>, the tradition of Loony Dook encourages the brave to swim in the icy waters of the River Forth. The city also offers performances, film screenings, and parades… and, to recover from the festivities, January 2<sup>nd</sup> is also a holiday.

events.title: January 25: Burns Night (national)
events.description: On January 25<sup>th</sup> 1759, Robert Burns, “Scotland's favourite son”, and one of the country's most famous poets, was born. To celebrate the event each year, the Scots gather at nightfall around a traditional meal, punctuated by speeches and lectures, and eat the famous haggis, a dish prepared with stuffed mutton, about which Burns wrote, 'Address to a Haggis'.

events.title: Friday before Easter: Good Friday (national)
events.description: As in the rest of the United Kingdom, Good Friday is a bank holiday in Scotland (while Easter Monday is not).

events.title: April 30–May 1: Beltane Fire Festival (local)
events.description: The people of Edinburgh celebrate the coming of summer with an immense Celtic festival. Costumes, lights, and music make for a delightful night. In the morning, the crowd climbs up to Holyrood to wash their face in the dew of the park.

events.title: May 1: May Day (national)
events.description: To celebrate the arrival of spring, the Scottish capital is the scene of an official parade: kilts and bagpipes are a must!

events.title: Last Monday in May: Spring bank holiday (national)
events.description: Historically, banks alone were closed on this day, but it has now become a holiday for all the people of Britain.

events.title: First Monday in August: Summer bank holiday (national)
events.description: August traditionally offers a holiday for workers. Be aware that it falls on the first Monday of the month in Scotland and the last Monday of the month in the rest of Great Britain.

events.title: Last three weeks of August: Edinburgh International Festival (local)
events.description: Every year since 1947, when it was created to celebrate the end of the war, this world-renowned cultural event has brought together a broad variety of musical events, as well as theatre, dance, and opera.

events.title: November 30: Saint Andrew's Day (national)
events.description: The patron saint of Scotland is celebrated throughout the country on November 30<sup>th</sup>. On the programme: festive meals, public performances of traditional dances and theatre, as well as pub-crawls.

events.title: December 25: Christmas Day (national)
events.description: This holiday is an opportunity for Scots to gather with family around the traditional Christmas Lunch.

events.title: December 26: Boxing Day (national)
events.description: A tradition from the Middle Ages, this holiday was the day when a present or gratuity was given to an employee, or a gift was given to the needy in addition to food distributions, and collections for the poor... In recent years, it has also become known as the day sales are launched in Britain.

events.title: December 30-31: New Year's Eve
events.description: In Edinburgh, starting on December 30<sup>th</sup>, a torchlight parade is organized in the city. The Hogmanay Street Party, held from December 30<sup>th</sup> to January 1<sup>st</sup>, attracts tens of thousands of people each year. Bagpipe and pop music concerts precede the fireworks, set off at midnight.

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for the United Kingdom
administrativeProcedures.description:
As a French citizen, you do not need to obtain a visa if you will be visiting the United Kingdom for less than 90 days. You must be in possession of a national identity card or a passport valid for the proposed duration of your stay.

To enjoy peace of mind during your stay in Edinburgh and the United Kingdom, be sure to check with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in your home country for the latest travel information and recommendations. Comprehensive information that may be helpful for international visitors is also provided on the United Kingdom page of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs' website: https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files/united-kingdom/#

Tipping
In Edinburgh, as in the rest of Scotland, tipping is only common in restaurants, where one generally tips 10% to 15% of the bill. In bars, hotels and taxis, tipping is not expected.
